called noxalis because the defendant had the option, if the guilt of the slave was proved, of surrendering him to the plaintiffin lieu ofpaying the damages assessed: ‘praetor ait . . . si servus insciente domino fecisse dicetur, in iudicio adiciam “aut noxam dedere ''' Dig. p 3. r. pr. N oxal actions are thus not a class of remedies apart by themselves, but only 'ordinary amiens on delict or quasi-delict (Dig. loc. cit), in which the defendant, being sued on a wrong not of bis own commission, is allowed by special provision (i 4 inf.) a privilege which, had the offence been his own, be would not have enjoyed. In principle, though not in form, they are arbitrariae (Tit. 6. 31 supr.) ς the noxae deditio is not made in accord· anne with the judge’s arbitrium, but the defendant is condemned in the alternative, Tit 17. 1 inf. lf the slave died before litis contestatio in the action, the masters liability ended, even though his death was unknown, Dig. 9. 4 39. 4 ; ib. 42· 1 : by his death during the action the master's liability in damages became absolute, ib. 3.

It has been conjectured that noxal actions were originally the expres· sion of an absolute claim to bave the offender delivered up for the exercise of private vengeance, whether bis offense were delictual or merely breacb of contract. The surrender of Postumius to the Samnites by the Romans with all the forms ol noxae deditio (Livy ix ro) was madeas atonement for non-observanee of the treaty which hebed concluded with them, and from which tbe Romans wished to release themselves-ut populus re· ligione solvatur. Under Roman municipal law non-fulfilment of a promise made by sponsio entailed, in tbe end, quasi-slavery (manus iniectio); and the idea was consistently applied by them in intemational relations,- cf. lbering, Gu‘st des r. Rechts i. p. 131 ; Mr. O. W. Holmes' Common Law pp. 8-12, and Mt. Poste’s note on Gaius iv. 81.
